Somewhat strengthening my view as I read more.  1) Goldman Sachs' research questions whether 2,000/wk rate can be sustained (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/10/goldman-sachs-cuts-tesla-price-target-predicts-model-3-disappointments-and-capital-raise.html): "We believe the sustainable production rate for the second quarter of 2018 is most likely below the 2,000 vehicle mark the company achieved in the final week of the [first] quarter," Goldman analyst David Tamberrino wrote Tuesday. "We see the company likely sustaining Model 3 production around the 1,400 per week mark." 2) Tesla's official target is to reach 5,000/wk by end of June. I recalculated total deliveries assuming that weekly rate rises linearly from its current rate to 5,000/wk for the last week of June and I got ~58,000 deliveries, which is not much higher than the 50k threshold for this question (thereby not leaving much room for error). Since I assume the target is optimistic (as they usually are), I consider this to be unlikely. The assumption of linear growth in the weekly rate might also be too optimistic.

If we take Bloomberg's estimate of deliveries at face value we are currently at 14,357 (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/) with 12 weeks to go. This seems congruent with numbers from the NYT (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/03/business/tesla-model-3.html) suggesting ~2400 built in 2017, Verge (link below) suggesting ~9700 built in Q1 2018 and and the ~2000/week reported number for the first week of April. The weekly rate has been steadily rising so it probably make sense to assume some increase over time. An optimistic take might be to fit an exponential curve to the historical Bloomberg data. Using this I got that by week 12 from now deliveries will be ~5,000 per week and that in total the deliveries by July 1 will be just over 50,000.  Since this seems like an optimistic model (for example, it might make more sense to use a logistic growth curve to reflect an eventual tapering off consistent with physical constraints), I place most of my probability distribution under 50,000.  Indeed, some reports (https://www.theverge.com/2018/4/3/17192312/tesla-goal-model-3-elon-musk) suggest that the recent jump >2000/week has come on the back of a concerted push within the company, casting some doubt as to whether this can be sustained.

Updating from 80/20/0/0/0 due to sales report for January 2018 [1]. It seems like Tesla sold 1875 Model 3s in January. Since sales are not deliveries, this is a slight overestimate. (One might worry that this is NEW sales and does not count deliveries to pre-ordered customers, but if you look at the 2017 chart on the same website you see that they are counting the pre-ordered customers.) That works out to <425 cars per week. A bit strange, since Tesla claimed to have hit (a speed that extrapolates to) 1000 cars/week in the last few days of 2017 [2]. So that figure seems to have been unrepresentative or downright misleading. (I watched a debate among auto industry experts, which I can't find now, that corroborates this. They were essentially making fun of Tesla's various technical claims, e.g. "of course when you get the production line going it produces cars very fast, but that's meaningless if the line has to stop a lot because of robot failures or missing parts or whatever".) Let's look at this from another angle. The best month for any single electric car ever was December 2016, when the Model S sold 5.8k units (in the US) [2]. The Model 3 has sold under 4k units to date, so there are 46k to go in 5 months. That works out to 9.2k cars/month, or 57% more than the best month ever for any electric car. (I'm only going to consider US deliveries for this question because Tesla itself admits it won't deliver Model 3s outside the US until late 2018 [3].) Given these considerations, I'm halving my forecast of >50k to 10%, but will keep watching for the Feb numbers. [1] https://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/

Those of us who have forecast on Tesla and SpaceX promises know that Elon Musk's deadlines aren't to be taken very seriously. To date, ~1.8k Model 3s have been delivered, 222 in 2017q3 [1] and 1550 in 2017q4 [2]. (There are 860 "in transit".) Even if we take Tesla at their word in [2], it seems extremely unlikely we'd get anything over 100k. They claim: (i) in last few days of 2017q4, ~1000 cars/week; 
(ii) plan to reach 2500 cars/week at end of 2018q1 
--> say (1000+2500)/2 = 1750 cars/week average in 2018q1
(iii) plan to reach 5000 cars/week at end of 2018q2 
--> say (2500+5000)/2 = 3750 cars/week average in 2018q2 
(iv) 13 weeks in each quarter 
--> 13*1750 + 13*3750 = 71500 total produced in 2018 before deadline Even if every single one is delivered, that leaves us below 75k total. No chance we break 100k. On the other hand, what would it take to go over 50k? Supposing the ones in transit get delivered, we are still 47,368 short. That's ~23.7k cars/quarter, almost as many Model Ss and Model Xs as Tesla sells each quarter, COMBINED. These are cars with mature production lines, which took years to put together, and years to ramp up to that kind of capacity [3]. The story being talked about right now (thanks to Musk) is how the production lines are difficult to put together, and certain segments of it keep breaking down or whatever. But remember the story for the Model X: back then it was that certain components weren't available, that the car "has thousands of unique components and there wasn't enough supply of only about a half dozen". Even if the production line issue gets fixed, who's to say there won't be a shortage of parts, or who knows what else? In my heart I think @dsarin is right to call >50k a 0% chance but I'm too chicken to go that far, so I'll go in between that and the crowd right now (38%, 280 forecasters) and call it 20%. I have a conundrum for anyone versed in statistics and probabilities (Or anyone else who has a thought): On this question, I'm betting that there is a 54% chance the answer will fall between 50k and 100k.  That's not only more than any other answer, it's more than all the other outcomes combined.   But, the consensus is at 62% between 50K and 100k.  So even if I win, I lose because the scoring is based on a curve. (Conversely, if the outcomes are either below 50k or between 100k and 200k, I'll get a decent score, even though the majority of my money is not on those outcomes.) So, if I'm trying to maximize my score, do I pull points from my outliers to match or exceed the consensus at 50k to 100k, or do I just go with where I'm at and hope that I (and the consensus) are wrong?

I was unfortunately a bit too optimistic with my initial forecast. After reading about Tesla production problems in the comments, I had to change my predictions. I now feel that even in the best circumstances of my initial prediction, it would be very hard to Tesla to reach 200 000 cars.  I do believe that Tesla will be able to overcome their production problems in the 4th quarter hence will be on track to produce between 100 000 to 200 000 cars. (Producing 600 cars per day starting December.) However there is a real possibility that they do not overcome their problems and are unable to even reach 600 cars per day. In the worst case scenario, they continue producing at their current rate hemce . I do not know how likely that would be but gave it an 10% chance. If Tesla manages to produce 300 cars per day, there will be on track to produce between 50 000 to 100 000 cars.

I do not know how many cars Tesla is capable of producing a day. However assuming that they have the capability to produce 800 cars per day, and are in production 6 days per week, over the next year, they would produce at most 235 200 cars. This brings the probability of producing 300 000 or more cars very close to 0. Cutting down their production by half to 400 cars per day, they would be producing about 100 000 cars per day. Things might go wrong with Tesla productions so there's a chance that less than 100 000 cars will be produced. I gave it a 10% chance to happen.

This is my forecast - so if you are looking for comparison take this with a grain of salt.  The most recent numbers I could see from Tesla's own target for PRODUCTION (distinction between delivery) is pegged at about 150,000 for the year. With the optimism and transparency of Elon Musk, I find it difficult to believe he would underpromise in order to over deliver. Additionally, there are concerns about battery production and mining of Lithium needed for the cars - which may or may not affect Tesla in 2017. In terms of delivery vs. production - I imagine there will be a slight delay in delivery times. I'm factoring about a 1-week delivery time from final production (Here is a post from a customer in 2016 asking about delivery times https://forums.tesla.com/forum/forums/how-long-production-when-vehicle-enters).

Looking into how automotive production line automation has changed, I believe that usual assumptions about failures, delays, downtime, etc may be wrong and may be substantially decreasing. Platforms such as Zero Downtime and KUKA Connect, and innovations such as KUKA Pulse, are only a piece of a growing changing puzzle in which automation is itself being automated, virtualized, and made more efficient with machine learning and data analytics:

Tesla delivered marginally more than 20k vehicles in Q4 2016, Q1 2017, and Q2 2017. I trust that they are installing in manufacturing capacity to increase manufacturing. The former NUMMI plant at its peak produced over 300k cars, which suggests Tesla should at least have space to grow. Capacity would be added in tranches which suggests that the question can be broken down into two:
1. How quickly can Tesla ramp up production
2. How much production would be allocated to Tesla 3 Current capacity is a 55:45 split between S:X, with close to 50k vehicles made in a half year. Tesla would have to grow manufacturing by 200% simply to hit 100k Model 3s and not grow Model S or Model X production, which also seems unlikely. Given that the orders on books have no firm delivery date, Elon Musk should be comfortable with letting the orders stay on the books. By doing more investigation into the installation pace, there could be a better answer for how much growth is at the Fremont Plant. For now, I'm hedging a 100% growth is more reasonable, slotting the delivery volume close to 50k +/- depending on efficiency gains.

Tesla currently produces 2000 units/wk of non-Model 3 cars. Their goal is to reach 5000/wk of Model 3 cars by the end of this year with a goal of 10,000/wk by Dec 2018. Based on Elon Musk's description of anticipated production "hell", I believe Tesla will experience difficulty rapidly reaching its target and that the first production cars won't leave the factory until Oct. Tesla just borrowed $1.5 b in debt (grade B-) as a cash cushion and has apparently structured these bonds to allow for repayment potentially after the first cars are sold. This will buy the company more time and allow it to slowly ramp up production while troubleshooting unanticipated delays. Incidentally, Tesla reports that there is a waiting list of over 400,000 buyers. Assuming a gradual linear increase in weekly production of Model 3s starting in October, I predict that they will produce approx 2000 cars/wk in Oct and increase by 500/wk every month thereafter. Thus, my best estimate is 8000 (Oct) + 10000 (Nov) + 12000 (Dec) + 14000 (Jan) + 16000 (Feb) + 18k + 20k + 22k + 24k = 144k. I also believe the odds of underproduction are significantly higher than overproduction. https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2017/08/07/business/ap-us-tesla-model-3.html

Musk's estimates are typically somewhat optimistic regarding the timeframe. Therefore I expect there to be some delays and as a consequence significantly less than 200k and maybe even less than 100k deliveries this year. On the other hand the questions closes end of June next year and there I could easily see Tesla delivering 200k+ cars. The <100k are if Tesla ceases operation within the next year and will be revised soon. The main contenders are 100k+ and we should have a better idea of them in September/October.
Taking the 83,000 estimate for 2017 and putting that rate into the first half of 2018 then somewhere between 100,00 and 200,000 seems to be the safest bet.

Based on last year's delivery levels for all Tesla models (http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=1006161). While Tesla will undoubtedly increase production above last year's numbers, and with an estimated 83K to be delivered by the end of 2017 (http://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-3-deliveries-83k-2017/), I think it'll be a challenge for them to break the 200K mark at this point.
